Class Storyteller

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • java.awt.Window
          • java.awt.Frame
            • javax.swing.JFrame
              • storyTellerPackage.Storyteller
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants

    public class Storyteller
extends javax.swing.JFrame
    Implementation of the tool for playing stories.

    Clean up

    There are various ways to close storyteller. By hitting CMD-Q on Mac, by quitting through the File menu Quit option, by closing the window using the window manager and by killing the application. With the exception of the first and the last one, we catch all of the other exits to do a proper clean up. The clean up consists in saving custom storyteller properties to disk, and telling the server that we are quitting, so it frees whatever resources being used for the current session.

    When hitting CMD-Q clean up tasks must be done through custom shutdown hooks: Runtime.addShutdownHook(Thread).

    Why don't logout the session before quitting instead of using shutdown hooks? Because we think that when hitting CMD-Q in Mac the best place to call the cleanup is in the shutdown hooks. The CMD-Q Mac event is not well integrated into the java event model, so we found no other obvious place to do the clean up.

    However we do have a handler for the CMD-Q event (quit()). It is used for showing a save dialog if the current story has some progress to save. We do not make the clean up there, however, because we don't know in which thread the quit handler is executed. We don't want to do the clean up in the event thread.

    The StorytellerRemote.logout(String) server method is called every time storyteller is closed and it is not hooked to a running instance of Swat. This is the case when constructed with Storyteller(String, boolean). It is possible that the logout method be not called if Storyteller is told to terminate the virtual machine on closing, that's the case when passing true as argument of the constructor above. Therefore, the clean up is delegated to the shutdown hooks that the caller of storyteller constructor must register himself.

    If storyteller is constructed with #Storyteller(StorytellerRemote, String, Deikto, JFileChooser, com.storytron.swat.Swat.LogDownloaderThread), then we assume there is a Swat instance, and the method StorytellerRemote.closeStoryteller(String) will be called when closing storyteller. This is so to preserve some session data on the server that may be needed to run log lizard from swat.

    Before calling any of these server cleanup methods, custom storyteller properties are saved to disk in all of the circumstances mentioned above, except when shutdown hooks are needed to make the clean up (when the programmer must register a hook that saves the properties, too).

      • Storyteller

        public Storyteller(StorytellerRemote str,
                   Deikto tkd,
                   javax.swing.JFileChooser chooser,
                   Swat swat,
                   Swat.LogDownloaderThread logDownloader,
                   java.lang.String login,
                   java.lang.String password)
        Parameters:
        logDownloader - is the thread that will donwload the logger data, when available. the Swat.LogDownloaderThread#wakeup() method should be called on this thread to announce availability of data. The log downloader will poll periodically until the method Swat.LogDownloaderThread#gotosleep() is called again. If logging must not be enabled pass null in this argument.
